verses.verse: (1 He giveth thanks to the Lord for his merciful works toward his Church,10 and declareth wherein true wisdom and right knowledge consisteth. ) I will praise the Lord with my whole heart in the assembly and the congregation of the just.

The works of the Lord are (He showeth that God’s works are a sufficient cause wherefore we should praise him, but chiefly his benefits toward his Church.) great, and ought to be sought out of all them that love them.
His work is beautiful and glorious, and his righteousness endureth forever.
He hath made his wonderful works to be had in remembrance: the Lord is merciful and full of compassion.

He hath given (God hath given to his people all that was necessary for them, and will do still even for his covenant’s sake, and in this sense the Hebrew word is taken, Prov. 30:8 and 31:15.) a (Or, prey, and food.) portion unto them that fear him: he will ever be mindful of his covenant.
He hath showed to his people the power of his works, in giving unto them the heritage of the heathen.

The (As God promised to take the care of his Church: so in effect doth he declare himself just and true in the government of the same.) works of his hands are truth and judgment: all his statutes are true.
They are established forever and ever, and are done in truth and equity.
He sent redemption unto his people: he hath commanded his covenant forever: holy and fearful is his Name.

(They only are wise, that fear God, and none have understanding, but they that obey the word.) The beginning of wisdom is the fear of the Lord: all they that observe (To wit, his commandments, as verse 7.) them, have good understanding: his praise endureth forever.
